meta.content: In this paper, we describe a facile new synthetic method for making highly dispersed molybdenum disulfide nanoparticles (~ 3 nm) on Ketjenblack carbon (MoS2/KC) via particle incorporation and sequential sulfidation. The MoS2/KC nanocatalyst obtained showed a good onset potential value (0.83 V), high durability, and excellent methanol tolerance for the oxygen reduction reaction. We report a simple method for making highly dispersed molybdenum disulfide nanoparticles (~ 3 nm) on Ketjenblack carbon support for sustainable oxygen reduction reactions with good onset potential, high durability, and excellent methanol tolerance.

meta.content: A New Synthesis of Highly Dispersed MoS2 Nanoparticles on Ketjenblack Carbon for Sustainable Oxygen Reduction Reaction - Catalysis Letters

In this paper, we describe a facile new synthetic method for making highly dispersed molybdenum disulfide nanoparticles (~ 3 nm) on Ketjenblack carbon (MoS2/KC) via particle incorporation and sequential sulfidation. The MoS2/KC nanocatalyst obtained showed a good onset potential value (0.83 V), high durability, and excellent methanol tolerance for the oxygen reduction reaction. Graphic Abstract We report a simple method for making highly dispersed molybdenum disulfide nanoparticles (~ 3 nm) on Ketjenblack carbon support for sustainable oxygen reduction reactions with good onset potential, high durability, and excellent methanol tolerance.

div.div:
A New Synthesis of Highly Dispersed MoS
2
Nanoparticles on Ketjenblack Carbon for Sustainable Oxygen Reduction Reaction

header.h1:
A New Synthesis of Highly Dispersed MoS
2
Nanoparticles on Ketjenblack Carbon for Sustainable Oxygen Reduction Reaction

li.p:
216
Accesses

div.p:
In this paper, we describe a facile new synthetic method for making highly dispersed molybdenum disulfide nanoparticles (~ 3 nm) on Ketjenblack carbon (MoS
2
/KC) via particle incorporation and sequential sulfidation. The MoS
2
/KC nanocatalyst obtained showed a good onset potential value (0.83 V), high durability, and excellent methanol tolerance for the oxygen reduction reaction.

We report a simple method for making highly dispersed molybdenum disulfide nanoparticles (~ 3 nm) on Ketjenblack carbon support for sustainable oxygen reduction reactions with good onset potential, high durability, and excellent methanol tolerance.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS
2
), a graphite-like layered transition metal chalcogenide material, has been used for a variety of applications such as sensing, catalysis, and batteries [
1
,
2
,
3
]. In general, MoS
2
nanostructures have been prepared by the gas-phase reaction and hydrothermal reactions [
4
,
5
].

Carbon supports such as reduced graphene oxide (RGO) and carbon black were used to stabilize the active nanoparticles [
10
]. The nanoparticles incorporated in a conductive carbon support as a durable nanocatalyst could maintain the catalytically active surfaces by preventing severe aggregation and agglomeration among particles during the ORR [
11
]. For example, MoS
2
on RGO and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with large surface areas and dynamic interaction showed enhanced catalytic performance for the ORR [
12
,
13
]. In addition, hierarchically porous carbon structures with MoS
2
were also very effective for improving mass transport and ion diffusion during ORR [
14
,
15
]
.

Meanwhile, zero dimensional (0D) colloidal MoS
2
nanoparticles (or nanodots) have very high surface-to-volume ratios with enhanced chemical activity due to a larger fraction of edge terminated, unsaturated S atoms compared to its 2D layered counterpart [
16
]. Until now, although some studies on MoS
2
nanostructures have been reported, there are few reports on highly dispersed MoS
2
nanodots supported on conductive carbon (Table S1, see Supporting information S1 for the literature review). In the present work, we introduce a new method for making highly dispersed MoS
2
nanoparticle (ca. 3 nm) incorporated into a conductive Ketjenblack carbon (KC) support. This was achieved by sonication of Mo colloid solution to embed the nanoparticles in the KC support and by calcination of MoO
3
/KC for sulfidation (Scheme
1
). First, the Mo nanoparticles could be prepared successfully by thermal decomposition of molybdenum carbonyl in the presence of stabilizing surfactants with the molar ratio 2.0 oleic acid/Mo. The method used was a modification of the method in our previous publication (detailed explanation is provided in Supporting Information) [
17
]
.

A brief scheme for the synthesis of MoS
2
/KC

Molybdenum hexacarbonyl (Mo(CO)
6
, 98.0%) was purchased from Strem. Oleic acid (C
18
H
34
O
2
, 90%), phenyl ether (C
12
H
10
O, 99.0%), sulfur powder (S, 99.98%), molybdenum(IV) sulfide powder (MoS
2
, 90 nm diameter, 99%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Pt/C catalyst (HiSPEC® 3000, Pt (20%) on carbon black) was purchased from Alfa Aesar. Nitric acid (HNO
3
, 60.0%) was purchased from SAMCHUN. Ketjenblack carbon (EC-300 J, 99.99%) was purchased from Lion Corporation.

Mo(CO)
6
(0.20 g, 0.75 mmol), as a white powder, and oleic acid (0.48 mL, 1.5 mmol) were dissolved in phenyl ether (15 mL). The mixture solution was heated to 310 °C under an inert gas. The reaction temperature was increased at a slow rate (11 °C min
−1
). Thereafter, to pyrolyze Mo(CO)
6
completely, the solution was stirred at the stated temperature for an additional 35 min and then cooled in an ice bath. The mixture produced was separated from the solution by adding excess ethanol and then centrifuging at 6000 rpm for 30 min.

KC powder (EC-300 J) was treated with nitric acid solution (10 M) for 15 min before use. The Mo nanopowder was dispersed and oxidized in ethanol (50 mL) by sonication for 15 min. Then, the MoO
3
dispersion in ethanol (20 mL) was mixed and sonicated with acid-treated KC (0.1 g) in ethanol (50 mL) for 150 min. Finally, MoO
3
/KC was obtained through the reaction and dried for further use. MoS
2
/KC was prepared from as-synthesized MoO
3
/KC. To produce a sulfide complex, excess sulfur powder (1.0 g) was added to the dried MoO
3
/KC powder. The mixture was placed in a tube furnace and heated at 400 °C for 4 h under a mixed H
2
/N
2
(1:3) gas flow at 200 mL min
−1
. Finally, MoS
2
/KC was obtained as a black powder.

The morphology of prepared nanocatalysts was investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) using a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin and a Talos F200X). Energy-disperse X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental mapping was performed using a higher-efficiency detection system (Super-X:4 SDD detectors). The phase of the as-synthesized catalysts was studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD, X’pert
3
Malvern Panalytical, Rigaku D/MAX-2500). XRD data were acquired in the 2
θ
range of 20–80°. The Raman spectra were collected using a FEX (NOST, Korea) Raman spectrometer to determine the
I
D
/
I
G
band ratio. An objective lens with a working distance of 50 × (NA = 0.5) was focused on the surface, and the excitation line at 531 nm was provided by a 0.3 mW excitation laser. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo scientific, UK) was employed to examine the surface chemical composition and valence state of the catalysts.

The electrochemical measurements were performed with a potentiostat (ZIVE SP1, ZIVE LAB) and modulated speed rotator (AFMSRCE, Pine Instruments) with a three-electrode system using a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode, graphite electrode as the counter electrode, and rotating glassy carbon electrode (RDE, geometrical area of 0.1963 cm
2
) as the working electrode. All measurements were conducted under the same conditions with the same catalyst loading on a working electrode film. To make the ink solution, 5 mg of the nanocatalyst was dispersed in a combination of 200 μL of DI water, 200 μL of isopropanol, and 20 μL of 5 wt% Nafion in an 8 mL vial and then sonicated for 1 h. With a micropipette, 7 μL of the catalyst ink was coated onto a glassy carbon rotating disk electrode and dried in an oven at 60 °C for 1 h. An O
2
-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution was utilized as the electrolyte to examine the electrochemical activity. More than thirty cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were performed at 1.2–0.02 V at 5 mV s
−1
in N
2
-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution to obtain reproducible results. The ORR polarization curves were obtained in the same potential range at 1600 rpm and corrected using 85% IR compensation to compare the activities of the three catalysts.

The Tafel values of the electrocatalysts were derived from these ORR polarization curves. The number of electrons transferred (
\(n\)
) was determined from the Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plot, constructed based on Eqs. (
1
–
3
).

Here,
\(J\)
represents the current density, while
\({J}_{K}\)
and
\({J}_{L}\)
are the kinetic current density and diffusion-limiting current density, respectively. The term
\(\omega\)
is the rotation rate of the RDE (
ω
= 2πN, N is the linear speed of the electrode),
\(F\)
is the Faraday constant (96,485 C mol
−1
), and
C
O
is the bulk concentration of oxygen in the electrolyte. Here,
D
O
is the diffusion coefficient of molecular oxygen in the bulk solution,
\(v\)
is the viscosity of the electrolyte,
\(k\)
is the electron transfer rate constant, and
\(n\)
is the overall number of electrons involved in the oxygen reduction reaction. The overall
\(n\)
value was obtained from the slope of the
J
−1
and
\(\omega^{ - 1/2}\)
plot constructed by exploiting the polarization curves acquired at 400–2400 rpm. Chronoamperometric measurements were carried out in O
2
-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at 0.55 V for 7 h to study the stability of the nanocatalysts.

The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the obtained Mo nanoparticles show very tiny particles (Fig.
1
a, b). The average particle size was 2.3 ± 0.4 nm, as determined by measuring 200 particles in TEM images (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The highly dispersed Mo nanoparticles were easily oxidized to MoO
3
nanoparticles even in air exposure during the separation and sampling processes for the next application. The Mo nanoparticles in ethanol were mixed with acid-treated KC powder followed by sonication to form the MoO
3
supported KC (MoO
3
/KC). Using sonication, the oxidized Mo nanoparticles were well-incorporated with KC.

a
Low-resolution TEM image and
b
HRTEM image of Mo nanoparticles,
c
TEM image,
d
HRTEM image, and
e
XRD spectrum of MoO
3
/KC

Very small dots on the carbon support were observed in the TEM image (Fig.
1
c and Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image shows MoO
3
nanoparticles (~ 3 nm) with lattice fringes in which 0.25 nm interspaces correspond to (310) lattice planes of MoO
3
(Fig.
1
d). In the XRD pattern, broad peaks in the 2
θ
range of 45°–70° were observed (due to the very small crystal size) that matched a hexagonal MoO
3
phase (JCPDS No. 21-0569) (Fig.
1
e). A broad and intense peak around 2
θ
= 26° mainly originated from the amorphous carbon nature of KC [
18
]
.

For the sulfidation of the MoO
3
, dried MoO
3
/KC was mixed with excess sulfur powder and thermally treated at 400 °C under a mixed gas flow of H
2
and N
2
for sulfidation. The reaction can occur as shown in the following equation.

After the thermal sulfidation process, the obtained MoS
2
nanoparticles on KC maintained their original size with no significant sintering (Fig.
2
a and Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). In the HRTEM image, the MoS
2
nanoparticles were observed to be around 3 nm (Fig.
2
b). The lattice distance of 0.26 nm between neighboring fringes well corresponded to the (012) lattice spacing of MoS
2
.

a
Low-resolution and
b
HRTEM image,
c
HAADF-TEM image,
d
,
e
Scanning TEM images with elemental mapping of Mo and S, and
f
XRD pattern of MoS
2
/KC

The high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF)-TEM image of MoS
2
/KC shows high MoS
2
dispersion and compact particle loading (Fig.
2
c). The elemental mapping of Mo (red) and S (blue) also indicate uniformly dispersed MoS
2
nanoparticles on the carbon support (Fig.
2
d, e). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectrum of MoS
2
/KC nanocatalyst was indexed to the hexagonal MoS
2
(Fig.
2
f, JCPDS No. 17-0744). A broad peak around 2
θ
= 26°, identically observed at the MoO
3
/KC sample, demonstrate that the peak originated from the KC support (Fig.
2
f). Other broad peaks at 2
θ
= 34° and 60° were assignable to the hexagonal MoS
2
phase (JCPDS No. 17-0744).

The Raman spectra reveal a D band at 1350 nm
−1
and G band at 1590 nm
−1
of KC for each sample (Fig.
3
a). The calculated
I
D
/
I
G
ratios of 1.08 at MoO
3
/KC and 1.07 at MoS
2
/KC were almost the same, indicating no structural damage during the calcination process. The surface species of the catalysts were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with a core-level of Mo 3
d
and S 2
p
. The Mo 3
d
spectra of MoS
2
/KC nanocatalyst show two strong peaks at 229.0 eV (3
d
5/2
) and 232.0 eV (3
d
3/2
), indicating a Mo
4+
oxidation state in MoS
2
(Fig.
3
b). Likewise, S 2p peaks were observed at 161.8 eV (2
p
3/2
), and 163.1 eV (2
p
1/2
), matched with S
2−
(Fig.
3
c).

a
Raman spectra of MoO
3
/KC and MoS
2
/KC, and XPS spectra of
b
Mo 3
d
and
c
S 2
p
for MoS
2
/KC

The electrocatalytic activity of the synthesized catalysts was investigated by applying the rotating disk electrode (RDE) technique. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) data was acquired in O
2
-saturated 0.1 M KOH with different revolutions per minute (from 400 to 2400) (Fig.
4
a). The MoS
2
/KC nanocatalyst shows high activity toward ORR. The current density of ORR could be enhanced by increasing the rotation speed from 400 to 2400 rpm. The Koutecky-Levich plots (K-L plots) were obtained from LSV curves and used to calculate the number of electrons at different potentials (Fig.
4
b). The number (n) of electrons transferred for the ORR calculated from the K-L slopes was 3.74. The MoS
2
/KC nanocatalyst showed a higher onset potential value (0.83 V) than those of commercial MoS
2
nanoparticles (0.73 V) and of conventional MoS
2
based nanocatalysts such as MoS
2
/rGO (0.80 V), commercial MoS
2
(0.73 V), and MoS
2
/CNT (0.61 V) (Table S2). Lowering of the over-potential by the high catalytic activity mainly originated from high dispersion of MoS
2
and interaction/cohesion between the MoS
2
nanoparticles and highly conductive KC support.

a
Steady-state voltammograms of the LSV curve at different rotation rates of MoS
2
/KC in O
2
-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution,
b
Corresponding K-L plot,
c
Chronoamperometry for 7 h of MoS
2
/KC and commercial Pt/C, and ORR polarization curves for
d
MoS
2
/KC nanocatalyst and
e
commercial Pt/C with and without 1.0 M methanol

Chronoamperometric measurements were performed at 0.55 V (vs. RHE) in an O
2
-saturated medium to examine the long-term durability of the MoS
2
/KC and commercial Pt/C catalysts. After 7 h, the MoS
2
/KC nanocatalyst retained 90.8% of its initial relative current density (Fig.
4
c). The result was superior to that of a commercial Pt/C catalyst (53.4%). The poor durability of the commercial Pt/C derives from Ostwald ripening [
19
]. Another limitation of a commercial Pt/C catalyst is its low methanol tolerance. The dehydrogenation of methanol occurs and CO forms and is adsorbed to Pt surfaces (CO
ad
). After that, adsorbed OH (OH
ad
) formed around or on the Pt catalysts react with CO
ad
, called the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism [
20
]. These methanol crossover effects due to toxic intermediates, and the associated low activity, limit the application of commercial Pt/C catalysts in fuel cells such as DMFCs.

The LSV curves of MoS
2
/KC nanocatalyst was almost the same before and after methanol injection (Fig.
4
d). This result means that the catalyst maintains high methanol tolerance in 0.1 M KOH solution and is thus not affected by this poisonous substance. On the other hand, commercial Pt/C exhibited a very high peak at 0.8 V due to the methanol oxidation reaction, resulting in decreased catalytic activity toward the ORR (Fig.
4
e).

In conclusion, highly dispersed MoS
2
nanoparticles on KC were simply prepared by MoO
3
incorporation under sonication and sequential thermal sulfidation. The obtained MoS
2
/KC exhibited high catalytic performance for the ORR based on electrochemical analyses in an alkaline solution. A good onset potential value (0.83 V), long-term durability (7 h), and high methanol resistance was achieved based on high particle dispersion (~ 3 nm) and on the intrinsic edge effects of the MoS
2
nanoparticles with strong cohesion property to the conductive KC support.
